qas.question: What are some of the reasons for a party's failure?

answers.text: political, social and economic circumstances, and public opinion

qas.question: What are some ways a dominant party can stay in power?

answers.text: patronage and sometimes by voting fraud

qas.question: What are some examples of dominant party systems?

answers.text: African National Congress in South Africa, the Cambodian People's Party in Cambodia

qas.question: For how long did the dominant one-party system last in mexico?
How likely is it that there was voting fraud in the 1998 election?

plausible_answers.text: political, social and economic circumstances, and public opinion

qas.question: What were the reasons for the Democratic Parties failure in 1990?

plausible_answers.text: patronage and sometimes by voting fraud

qas.question: What were two things that the Liberal Democratic Party in Japan used in the 1970's to try and win an election?

plausible_answers.text: the People's Action Party in Singapore, the African National Congress in South Africa, the Cambodian People's Party in Cambodia

qas.question: What are some parties that were guilty of using voter fraud?
How long did the People's Action Party in Singapore last?

context: <a0_0>In dominant-party systems<a0_0/>, opposition parties are allowed, and there may be even a deeply established democratic tradition, but other parties are widely considered to have <b5_0>no real chance<b5_0/> of gaining power. Sometimes, <a1_0><b6_0>political, social and economic circumstances, and public opinion<b6_0/><a1_0/> are the reason for others parties' failure. Sometimes, typically in countries with less of an established democratic tradition, it is possible the dominant party will remain in power by using <a2_0><b7_0>patronage and sometimes by voting fraud<b7_0/><a2_0/>. In the latter case, the definition between dominant and one-party system becomes rather blurred. Examples of dominant party systems include <b8_0>the People's Action Party in Singapore, the <a3_0>African National Congress in South Africa, the Cambodian People's Party in Cambodia<b8_0/><a3_0/>, the Liberal Democratic Party in Japan, and the National Liberation Front in Algeria. One-party dominant system also existed in Mexico with the Institutional Revolutionary Party <b9_0>until the <a4_0>1990s<b9_0/><a4_0/>, in the southern United States with the Democratic Party from the late 19th century until the 1970s, in Indonesia with the Golkar from the early 1970s until 1998.
